awd_titl_txt: UNS:  Collaborative Research: Global Agricultural Impacts of Stratospheric Aerosol Climate Intervention
awd_abstract_narration:
Injection of aerosols into the stratosphere, an approach known as stratospheric aerosol climate intervention, has been suggested as a strategy to compensate for anthropogenic global warming. Much research has focused on climate changes associated with stratospheric aerosol climate intervention (also called stratospheric aerosol geoengineering – SAG), but only a few studies have addressed its potential societal impacts, in particular global agricultural productivity. This project will examine how anticipated climate changes from SAG, compared with the present and a future without SAG, would interact with the global agriculture system, influence crop growth, and impact world food production. Spatially explicit climate changes considered here associated with SAG include less total solar radiation, more diffuse solar radiation, reduced surface temperature, changed precipitation, changed surface ozone concentration, and different global mean CO2 levels.

This project is a multidisciplinary collaboration to evaluate global agriculture impacts of SAG with an integrated assessment framework, including a state-of-the-art Earth System Model linked to multiple mechanistic crop models. These models are targeted to advance the frontier of process-based crop modeling with representations of ozone damage and diffuse radiation in photosynthesis processes. Impact uncertainties will be systematically quantified through the model ensemble setup and multi-crop model assessment, and by using different downscaling methods for climate forcing data. Detailed impacts of individual climate factors on crop yields will be studied, while considering feedbacks from the agriculture system to the anticipated SAG climate impacts. The results of this project will provide new quantitative evidence of SAG implications for world food production in view of present day and potential future climates without SAG. The project will foster communication between the climate modeling community (including the Geoengineering Model Intercomparison Project) and the crop modeling community (the Agricultural Model Intercomparison and Improvement Project), to advance understanding of agricultural impacts under global warming and a future climate with stratospheric aerosol intervention.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Our project investigated feedbacks from atmospheric geoengineering strategies aimed to offset global warming, in global agriculture. We studied impacts of stratospheric aerosol injection (SAI) in the upper atmosphere on surface-level temperature and precipitation patterns, and associated changes in crop productivity.

The global climate model CESM was used to simulate atmospheric responses and to inform multiple process-based crop models to evaluate impacts in global maize productivity. This pioneering project brought together researchers from multiple disciplines to advance our understanding of the uncertainties associated with atmospheric geoengineering, especially in agricultural systems.

This project yielded significant insights into the complex response mechanisms between SAI and crop growth. Global warming is largely driven by an increasing concentration of CO2 in the atmosphere, which in turn can be beneficial for crop productivity. Additionally, the fraction of diffuse and direct radiation affects photosynthesis as well. Aerosols in the atmosphere scatter incoming solar radiation and increase the fraction of diffuse light. Plant canopies can absorb a higher amount of radiation under diffuse light conditions compared to direct light. Therefore, stratospheric aerosols can amplify crop growth, resulting in complex feedback mechanisms that require detailed and process-based crop models to evaluate net changes in crop productivity. 

To address these complex and subtle processes, we advanced the well-known process-based crop model pDSSAT and equipped it with a process representation of diffuse light response. This allows the model to evaluate impacts under SAI in a more balanced way compared to models that cannot respond to changes in diffuse light. We then combined results from the pDSSAT model with results from two additional global gridded crop models, i.e. CLMcrop and LPJ-GUESS to address inherent uncertainties.

One of our critical findings of this project is that atmospheric aerosol injections would result in regionally heterogeneous effects with different temperature responses and different crop productivity responses. For example, some higher-latitude countries can potentially expect benefits in crop growth under moderate climate change without SAI implementation, while others require a substantial level of SAl to offset adverse future climate impacts. This finding highlights the complexity of designing global SAI strategies that could potentially be ratified by all nations. It also points to potential conflicting custom SAI strategies optimized to meet the specific needs of different regions.

The general response mechanisms to SAI are that the global surface temperature would decline to the targeted level (i.e. that is the idea of SAI), precipitation patterns respond in complex ways, atmospheric CO2 levels remain elevated as SAI does not remove CO2, and the injected aerosols will lead to a higher fraction of diffuse light. Many of these factors are theoretically beneficial for crop growth.  

However, our pilot project revealed substantial uncertainties associated with crop productivity responses to SAl. Forced with the same climate simulation (SSP2-4.5), but also sulfur injection that would limit the global mean temperature to 1.5°C above pre-industrial levels, the three process-based crop models show different responses. The pDSSAT model shows the most pessimistic responses with substantial adverse climate impacts in global maize productivity (-20%, SSP2-4.5). SAI would offset some of the losses but by mid-century the model indicates net losses of about 10% compared with the current reference level (SSP2-4.5 SAI-1.5C). CLMcrop shows more optimistic results with small losses associated with SSP2-4.5 that would be overcompensated by SAI and turn into net gains of about 3% globally. LPJ-GUESS is found to be largely insensitive with small climatic impacts and negligible differences to the SAI scenario. This can be explained by the fact that LPJ-GUESS cannot account for diffuse light, but also by the fact that the model is known for above-average CO2 fertilization effects even in C4 crops such as maize.

To derive more robust conclusions and to effectively inform policymakers about the impact of SAl in global agriculture, it is critical to conduct careful and more comprehensive follow-up assessments. These need to include multiple climate models to address climate model and scenario uncertainty, but also a much larger number of mechanistic crop models that have the required process representation and can reasonably respond to the complex feedback mechanisms of SAl injection.

Nevertheless, the outcomes of this pilot project are critical and first of its kind. They extend beyond scientific and technological advancements, fostering a deeper understanding of the broader societal implications of climate intervention strategies. Furthermore, the results of this project serve as a catalyst for further collaboration between climate and crop modeling experts, leading to a more comprehensive understanding of SAl implications.


References

Clark, B., Xia, L., Robock, A., Times, S., Richter, J., Visioni, D., Rabin, S. 2023: The optimal climate intervention scenario for crop production varies by nation. Nature Food, 4, 902-911, doi: 10.1038/543016-023-00853-3.

Clark, B., Robock, A, Xia, L., Rabin, S., Guarin, J., Jägermeyr, J. Maize Yield Changes under Sulfate Aerosol Climate Intervention Using Three Global Gridded Crop Models (submitted)
